gresults.text: I think you need a complementary team of DIFFERENT skills to make your business successful. Here's my blog post on that at LinkedIn: http://www.linkedin.com/today/post/article/20130326172231-9947747-why-you-need-a-complementary-team-to-succeed?trk=mp-reader-card I would love to hear your thoughts if you agree...

comments.text: nailed it
Correct - any weaknesses in one are compensated in another, and vice versa.

I spent a few years in the mid-90's working on the design of "fault tolerant" organizations, hoping to create information exchange pathways inside organizations that limited the harm that could be done through the loss or failure of any individual. The large scale experiment - the scaleable company that we were building - pretty much failed, ended up being rebuilt form the ground up on a different basis using contractor labor, in part because I had neither identified nor solved these problems and in part because we were working inside an existing organizational structure and not all the systems for necessary decentralization and elimination of single points of failure could be implemented.  

As much as the article's text, the image you chose to illustrate it speaks to the most interesting approach to this problem I have seen anyone take to date.

About 20 years ago, a good friend was running a nonprofit with a chronically dysfunctional board of directors. He gained access to a big pulling boat - 8 or 10 big oars on a lifeboat sized wooden hull - I think it was a replica of one of the launches on Capt Vancouver's ship - and he took the board out for a spin and steered them into serious currents, way out in the bay, and then disabled the rudder.  At which point they really had no choice (other than a tow from the Coast Guard) but to cooperate - at a truly physical level - to "listen" with their arms and backs and legs to one another's muscles on the other oars, and coordinate their efforts if they were to get back to the harbor. But whether or not a single experience like that can really change the way people deal with one another is another matter entirely.

This depends on the particular skills. Business types with no open source experience are often terrible when they are in a position of authority over open source developers. The profit model is entirely different and apparently incomprehensible unless they've either seen it up close or have very carefully studied, e.g. Cygnus and RHAT business models.

gresults.text: Every new technology goes through a period where people "port" the old to the new. Usually, about a decade in, people "invent" or discover the true meaning of the new medium. The possibilities with widely dispersed remote sensors are awesome - and they make phone calls.

She's on pace to reach port around Jan. 24, her lawyer Peter de Lange said on Wednesday, Jan. 11, 2010. (AP Photo/Judy Fitzpatrick, File)

comments.text: The Dutch tried to block her and delayed for a year.  The number of youth lost at sea seems to be tiny relative to their numbers. Very rare.  Amazing accomplishment but she was highly experienced and her parents saw her in action enough to trust her judgment.  Still, not for the average bay sailor.

Two issues I see, one the idea that one becomes mature at an arbitray age set by law, and the response by government that they somehow know what's best for someone rather that persons parents in the case.

Kids who sail off-shore with their parents tend to do great in school and due to contact with different cultures are better socially adjusted.

Besides, I would trust a 16 YO girl's judgment over an older boy's judgment. Something to do with brain development ...

With all of the teens falling through the cracks in education, and turning to drugs, subversive cultures, and just plain part of the "x" generation, why not applaud a young woman who sets a goal, accomplishes it, and shows early leadership skills in a generation where few like her are seen?

As anyone seen evidence that parents know more than a government agency about raising kids? At least most of the agency people have studied raising kids. Try to find parents who have studied how to raise teens. I have. Very rare. Mostly seat-of-the-pants and ad hoc training.

I've had hundreds of teens in foster care, Junior Achievement, Boy Scout leader at age 12, and so on.
Prior to public education I do believe parents knew how to raise their children.

+Jim Preston As anyone seen evidence that parents know more than a government agency about raising kids?

No, but I'd like to see some evidence that the converse is true too.

+Ralph Sevy Prior to public education I do believe parents knew how to raise their children.

Sure, because we had extended families in those days, and it wasn't uncommon for three generations of a family to live in the same home, or at least in the immediate vicinity. Kids growing up learned how to care for their younger brethren. That's not so true anymore.
